channel.title: USB As Ram? Whats your thoughts?
channel.description:
Recently i have installed my spare PSP memory stick to be used as ram. Yes, it is possible. But i want to know, what are your opinions about doing things like this? Please give a reason as well.
Personally, i love the idea, my computers speed has doubled, with only a 1GB Memory Stick-Pro-Duo. So yes, i am a supporter.

item.title: USB As Ram? Whats your thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

protip: most 32bit processors come with pae(physical address extension) which enables the os to address 2^36 bytes (64GB) of RAM.

As Moparisthebest said your method of “USB as RAM” which is just storing a pagefile on the flash is bad. USB 2.0 has a speed of only 480mb/s and most NAND chips are even slower and they have a limited number of read/writes which you will use up quickly if you use it with readyboost.

Read full topic
item.source: USB As Ram? Whats your thoughts?

item.title: USB As Ram? Whats your thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Like i said though, depending on your PC’s specs, it might just work to speed up your computer. I would have increasing the paging value on my hard-drive, but it is full. With only a 20GB hard drive, and a computer from 01 or 02, that takes about 10minutes to put a 350MB file onto a USB, its just not easy to clean up my harddrive.

Read full topic
item.source: USB As Ram? Whats your thoughts?

item.title: USB As Ram? Whats your thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

I’ve tried it and it doesn’t work very well. The USB is unable to read and write memory as fast as needed to do anything needing alot of ram.

Read full topic
item.source: USB As Ram? Whats your thoughts?

item.title: USB As Ram? Whats your thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It would be much faster if you just create a bigger ‘pagefile’ on your hard drive, since most hard drives are much faster than most USB sticks. It certainly isn’t remotely as fast as RAM.

Read full topic

item.source: USB As Ram? Whats your thoughts?

item.title: USB As Ram? Whats your thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Alright, i did a bit of Google searching and found some information that further explains the GB ‘limit’ on xp 32bit. I quote this:

Windows XP can and does utilize all of the ram. However, a user process only gets to use 2GB unless you invoke the 3GB switch. The remaining part of the virtual address space is used to map the system so that the user can get it to do things. Your client's system should run very fast with 4GB of ram. That extra GB is most definitely not wasted unless, of course, your client never read or writes to devices such as disks or monitors, never connects to a modem, never accesses the internet, etc. If you client never does any of those things, he does not need a computer. Jim

@o0o - What did you think? A bit hoax? People have been doing this for some time lol. Now to just figure out how to have a USB processor, and we can really utilize our PC’s performance.

Read full topic

item.title: USB As Ram? Whats your thoughts?
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

CoonHunter:

I dont know if this would work for Windows 7, since i do not have a computer with it. I do know it works for windows XP and Vista. I tested it on my uncles computer, that has Vista-Pro, and m personal computer that has XP-Pro. My computer ran VERY slowly, and it used to freeze when loading msn. Now i can load msn, and actualy see what happens when i am logging in.sslslow start to

You can use ReadyBoost with Windows 7.

Read full topic
